trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus queues (Python) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus queues (Python) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Service Bus queues from Python.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Service Bus queues from Python.

trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus queues
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus queues

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Python and use the <link><linkText>Python Azure package[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Python and use the <link><linkText>Python Azure package[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: Note: To install Python or the Python Azure package[], see the Python Installation Guide.
trans-unit.target: Note: To install Python or the Python Azure package[], see the Python Installation Guide.

trans-unit.source: How to create a queue
trans-unit.target: How to create a queue

trans-unit.source: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with queues.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with queues.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code near the top of any Python file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Service Bus:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code near the top of any Python file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Service Bus:

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Replace 'mynamespace', 'sharedaccesskeyname' and 'sharedaccesskey' with your namespace, shared access signature (SAS) key name, and value.
trans-unit.target: Replace 'mynamespace', 'sharedaccesskeyname' and 'sharedaccesskey' with your namespace, shared access signature (SAS) key name, and value.

trans-unit.source: The values for the SAS key name and value can be found in the Azure portal connection information, or in the Visual Studio Properties window when selecting the Service Bus namespace in Server Explorer (as shown in the previous section).
trans-unit.target: The values for the SAS key name and value can be found in the Azure portal connection information, or in the Visual Studio Properties window when selecting the Service Bus namespace in Server Explorer (as shown in the previous section).

trans-unit.source: create_queue also supports additional options, which enable you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.
trans-unit.target: create_queue also supports additional options, which enable you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.

trans-unit.source: The following example sets the maximum queue size to 5GB, and the time to live value of 1 minute:
trans-unit.target: The following example sets the maximum queue size to 5GB, and the time to live value of 1 minute:

trans-unit.source: How to send messages to a queue
trans-unit.target: How to send messages to a queue

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, your application calls the send\_queue\_message method on the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, your application calls the send\_queue\_message method on the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named taskqueue using send\_queue\_message:
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named taskqueue using send\_queue\_message:

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.

trans-unit.source: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: How to receive messages from a queue
trans-unit.target: How to receive messages from a queue

trans-unit.source: Messages are received from a queue using the receive\_queue\_message method on the ServiceBusService object:
trans-unit.target: Messages are received from a queue using the receive\_queue\_message method on the ServiceBusService object:

trans-unit.source: Messages are deleted from the queue as they are read when the parameter peek\_lock is set to False.
trans-unit.target: Messages are deleted from the queue as they are read when the parameter peek\_lock is set to False.

trans-unit.source: You can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the parameter peek\_lock to True.
trans-unit.target: You can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the parameter peek\_lock to True.

trans-unit.source: The behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: The behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: If the peek\_lock parameter is set to True, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: If the peek\_lock parameter is set to True, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling the delete method on the Message object.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling the delete method on the Message object.

trans-unit.source: The delete method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.
trans-unit.target: The delete method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.

trans-unit.source: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages
trans-unit.target: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock method on the Message object.
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock method on the Message object.

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.target: Next steps
